text_a: Multiply the two original denominators and use their products as a common denominator
text_b: All right the lesson you guys did on Monday or Tuesday with Mrs Porter you did a really great job almost every single person got a three on the exit slip
That showed me you really understood finding equivalent fractions
Were going to be using that idea today to continue our work with finding common denominators
Im going to be teaching you several different ways to find common denominators were going to start with a little video to get you guys your brains into
Please
Oh youre Dan and Jonah I want to know how to add and subtract fractions from Joshua
Pies are perfect for talking about fractions
As you can see this is one pie thats one part of one whole or one over one in fraction form
If I cut the pie right down the middle I get two pieces each piece is one divided by two or one half of the whole
One half plus one half equals two halves or one whole
In a fraction the numbers have names the top number is the numerator and the bottom number is the denominator
The denominator tells us how many pieces make up one whole the numerator tells us how many of those pieces were dealing with
The two in this case is a common denominator shared by both fractions
When you add fractions with the same denominator you add the numerators while the denominator stays the same
Each of these pieces is one divided by four or one fourth of the whole we can see that one fourth plus one fourth equals two fourths or one half
Lets say we want to add one fourth of this pie to one half of another one
Cutting pie one fourth and one half are fractions with different denominators
To add them we need to find their LCD or lowest common denominator
Its basically the lowest common multiple of the fractions denominators
For our denominators two and four that number is four we want to write all of our fractions as fractions of four
One fourth already is and as we saw before one half and two fourths are really the same thing
Now that we have a common denominator we can just add the numerators two fourths plus one fourth equals three fourths
Subtraction is the same idea
As long as we have a common denominator its just a matter of subtracting the numerators
If we dont have a common denominator we find the lowest common denominator and rewrite our fractions to match
Heres a good example

Last year Jonahs pies were the highest selling items in the bake sale in fact five ninths of all the students in our school bought them but the year before only five twelfths of the school bought the pies
Come on it was the first year you made them people didnt know how good they were yet
Anyway to find out what fraction of students bought the pies the second year but not the first year we would subtract five twelfths from five ninths
The denominators are nine and 12 whats the LCD
Good 36
Thats the lowest number that both nine and 12 multiply into evenly
Lets rewrite our fractions as fractions of 36

Lets see to turn nine into 36 we need to multiply by four which means we also have to multiply the numerator by four and to turn 12 into 36 we multiply by three which means we can also multiply five by three
Now we can just subtract the numerators to get our answer between last year and the year before your sales increased by five 36ths
